Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Spatial Analysis into Archaeological Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Spatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations (SPARC)Program promotes the use of spatial analysis, 3D modeling, aerial and geophysical remote sensing technologies in archaeological research projects around the world. The increasing availability and sophistication of these technologies and methods profoundly affects how archaeologists and other scholars work. The things archaeologists study - from artifacts to sites to landscapes - almost always have a spatial component, and for many decades space has been viewed as one of the central dimensions of archaeological study. The capabilities of geospatial technologies to enhance the discovery and interpretation not only offers new data, but also creates entirely novel means of engaging with the archaeological record. Through the SPARC Program high impact projects seeking to explore and implement geospatial technologies and methods are selected based on peer reviewed applications. Their work is supported through close collaborations with experts in spatial archaeometry at The University of Arkansas' Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies (CAST), the University of Glasgow and Dartmouth University. Together, the teams at these institutions form a center for innovative geospatial research and methods in archaeology. Technical experts and research staff at CAST, Dartmouth and Glasgow actively promote geospatial technologies in archaeology, and collaborate with the selected projects, providing access to equipment, methodological and domain expertise, and intensive training.

The Program's goals are to: enhance the research productivity of archaeological projects by making geospatial technologies available to researchers who would not otherwise have access to the tools or skills needed to collect and analyze these data; directly generate high value archaeological data by participating in fieldwork and analytical projects to efficiently collect and analyze geospatial data; provide training opportunities for students and professionals seeking to use geospatial techniques in their own research; promote the development of new geospatial methods and applications in archaeology and the visibility of these innovations in the broader archaeological community; and support good practice and promote innovation in archiving and publication of digital geospatial data. The new support from the NSF Archaeometry program will allow SPARC to continue building a program that is increasingly visible - attracting top research projects; efficient - as project staff build on their experience; high impact - as pilot projects build skills in research teams around the world; and innovative - with broader collaborations leading to significant methodological advancements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SPARC Program promotes and supports the application of geomatics methodologies and technologies in archaeological research by providing access to the Program?s core institutions? (University of Arkansas, Dartmouth College, and the University of Glasgow) facilities and expertise to a broad community of researchers and students through research collaborations. SPARC helps researchers with existing grant funding make money go further, by offering essential geospatial consulting, field data collection, collaboration on analytical projects, and post-collection data processing and analysis that would not otherwise possible.  The Program?s focus is in three primary areas the core institutions? expertise: 1) site-based archaeo-geophysics and mapping, 2) three-dimensional scanning, photogrammetry, visualization and morphometrics and 3) aerial and satellite remote sensing, regional survey, and mapping.

In 2017-2018 continued NSF support for the SPARC Program enabled the team to collaborate on a series of projects focused on analytical work and the publication of the results of fieldwork previously supported through SPARC. New publications featured the results of projects including SPARC supported magnetometry survey at Dionisio Point, ground penetrating radar survey in Oman, and multi-method survey in the South Caucasus. Support in 2017-2018 also enabled work on a set of projects facilitating the creation, aggregation and publication of geospatial data through online platforms. These projects include collaborations on platforms like GeoPACHA (https://geopacha.cast.uark.edu/) focused on exploiting increasingly available satellite imagery in South America. To date SPARC collaborations have enabled 50 researchers to integrate spatial archaeometric techniques into 34 projects carried out around the world.

The growing availability and power of digital geospatial technologies increasingly affects how archaeologists and other scholars work. The things archaeologists study?from artifacts to sites to landscapes?almost always have a spatial component, and the capabilities of geospatial technologies to enhance the discovery and interpretation of these features not only offers new data, but creates entirely novel means of engaging with the archaeological record.  SPARC collaborations help researchers to engage with a variety of new and emerging technologies, enhancing their own work. Through collaborative projects, SPARC researchers are encouraged to innovate: developing new methods and techniques in geospatial data acquisition, analysis, visualization and integration targeted specifically for the challenges of archaeological research. SPARC collaborations have led to innovative applications in areas such as large scale detailed path modeling, integrated remote sensing and ground based survey in neo-tropical forests, and geophysical survey in woodlands.

Training and exposure to new techniques through SPARC collaborations expand the research capacity of participants, giving them the tools to integrate geospatial technologies into their future projects, with long term impacts on their research. Many projects supported through SPARC are field schools and a significant number of graduate students and post-doc students learn to incorporate advanced technologies and methodologies into their ongoing research. Local partners of SPARC collaborators benefit from what is often their first exposure to archaeo-geomatics and archaeo-geophysics. This is particularly important for projects carried out in nations and regions without well-developed educational resources or access to training opportunities. The Program has important impacts locally on the research and education environment at SPARC institutions, exposing their students to a wide variety of projects pursuing cutting-edge research.
